-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                       Description
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What ghastly days these have been for Pakistan following Benazir Bhutto&#039;s 
assassination! And what a grim shock for an already crisis-weary world, which 
did not need more hair-raising turmoil, and even speculation about possible 
civil war, in what&#039;s often called "the most dangerous place on earth".

One can scarcely imagine a more volatile mix of explosive dangers than Pakistan. 
It&#039;s a nuclear power with 165 million people and a potential flashpoint for 
conflicts that can affect the whole of Central Asia and the Middle East - 
perhaps the whole world. So we&#039;ve every right to be very concerned about what 
happens next.

In this week&#039;s show, we look beyond the assassination and ask what can be done, 
for in crises like this it&#039;s always wise to seek out the calm voices in a 
storm; those who have a strong historical grasp of the situation and take the 
long view of events. That&#039;s what we do in part two of our show in an in-depth 
interview with Akbar Ahmed, a highly respected former Pakistani diplomat, 
author and professor of international relations at American University in 
Washington, DC.

But we start with a reminder of the high stakes involved for other nations - 
Canada most definitely included - and an item Brian did for the National 
immediately following the assassination.
